description: The combination of the secret discloser (a narrative technology in which a narrator shares an intimate secret about a character) with wish fulfillment (a plot technology that shows a character getting everything they want)
name: Almighty Heart

description: The combination of the secret discloser (a narrative technology in which a narrator shares an intimate secret about a character) with wish fulfillment (a plot technology that shows a character getting everything they want) and a narrator who gently mocks some or all characters
name: Almighty Heart + Satiric Narration

description: The combination of the secret discloser (a narrative technology in which a narrator shares an intimate secret about a character) with wish fulfillment (a plot technology that shows a character getting everything they want) and soliloquy (a character who reveals a conflict that you have experienced, prompting identification)
name: Almighty Heart + Soliloquy

description: A narrative technology that links nonsensical or absurd ideas together with poetic patterns like rhyme or meter.
name: Anarchy Rhymer

description: An expression of regret for wrong actions; a recognition of the harm done
name: Apology

description: Purging something unhealthy. As theorized by Aristotle, the unhealthy thing was fear.
name: Catharsis

description: A life story that presents an existential journey (from the past) and a way of understanding it (from the time of writing) without suggesting that it will be the way to make meaning of other existential journeys.
name: Choose Your Own Accomplice

description: Any moment where an actor breaks the stage's fourth wall to assure us: "None of this is really real"
name: Comic Wink

description: When a story has a narrator who winks at the viewer/reader to indicate "this isn't real" but presents an alternate reality in the form of an absurd or unrealistic plot, character, or storyworld.
name: Comic Wink + Reality Shifter

description: When a narrator explains their discovery that they were ignorant to a truth they now see
name: Conversion Narrative

description: Two or more narrators who disagree in their evaluation of the storyworld and characters they convey
name: Disagreeing Narrators

description: A narration technology that shows a narrator making mistakes in judgment while encountering a new culture, but then struggling to decide which culture is best (the familiar becomes somewhat unacceptable and the unfamiliar becomes only somewhat acceptable).
name: Double Alien

description: A narrative that moves between two different worlds, not settling with any certainty which is the "real" world.
name: Dream of the World

description: Allowing the audience to experience the true remorse of a character
name: Empathy Generator

description: A plot element that is an impossibility
name: Enigma

description: A simile that takes a non-human thing (an animal, a plant, etc.) and offers it as a metaphor for the human experience.
name: Epic Simile

description: A love triangle in which neither choice is obviously wrong. Unlike a regular love triange, where one choice is clearly right (or seems right until new information is revealed), this love triangle presents a world in which there is not only one choice for love.
name: Equilateral Love Triange

description: A narrator who can ventriloquize a character (often ironically), speaking as them instead of conveying what they actually said with direct quotation.
name: Free Indirect Discourse

description: A narrative technology that expresses the power and knowledge of a divine being and the knowledge of subjective human experience. Seen in scripture—“forceful, austere, and unequivocal.” “It allows anyone with a pen to sound like a deity,” making it possible to “touch the minds of audiences with two powerful emotions: wonder and fear" (Fletcher 34).
name: God Voice

description: A narrative technology that expresses gratefulness for a world creator and stretches that into a spiritual gratitude for everything that we see
name: Gratitude Booster

description: A plot technology that "abandons the usual forward momentum of plots in favor of a drifting, eddying, dilating story that provides us with time to acknowledge our heartache and dwell upon memories of our loved ones lost" (Fletcher 138).
name: Grief Releaser

description: A character who is frustrated with clichéd performances of grief and insists on truly honoring the life of the departed (Fletcher 138).
name: Guilt Lifter

description: A situation in which a character is not guilty of a moral crime, but has instead made "a mistake of perception, like a misheard word or a moment of blurred vision" (Fletcher 67)
name: Hamartia

description: A narrative technology that expresses the power and knowledge of a divine being and the knowledge of subjective human experience.
name: Human God Voice

description:
A plot technology in which a character suffers a trauma but doesn't acknowledge it until later. This places us, the audience, in the position of knowing the trauma before it's felt by the character. 

Identified as Anagnorisis by Aristotle in Poetics 1452a
name: Hurt Delay

description: A narrator who speaks in the first person
name: I Voice

description: A narration technology that implies an insult but does not make it directly
name: Insinuation

description: Revealing a truth that a character (and also the reader) doesn't see" or revealing that a character doesn't see something that the reader can see (while nudging readers to notice what they are missing in their own lives)
name: Irony

description: A narration technology that combines past-tense self-love and present tense self-irony
name: Life Evolver

description: A rhetorical technology in which a speaker (perhaps a narrator, if this occurs within a story) works methodically toward an argument, providing evidence for claims presented.
name: Logic

description: A plot technology that arbitrarily assigns good outcomes to characters
name: Lucky Twist

description: A narration technology that draws attention to the fact that the story being conveyed is a horror story, complete with all of the typical features present in the genre
name: Meta-Horror

description: An appeal to morality in order to influence or change behavior
name: Moral Suasion

description: A story that holds no stable meaning and would prompt confusion unless the viewer or reader supplies their own beliefs to make sense of it.
name: Narrative without Core Values

description: Constructing a story in which characters display many emotions, perhaps unpredictably, encouraging the viewers or readers to observe and recognize the emotions they are experiencing.
name: Opportunity to Observe

description: Constructing a story in which characters display many emotions, perhaps unpredictably, encouraging the viewers or readers to observe and recognize the emotions they are experiencing and then giving that story an ending that generates positive emotions
name: Opportunity to Observe + Pivot into Positive Emotion

description: A simple story illustrating a moral or religious lesson
name: Parable

description: A narration technology of exaggerated imitation
name: Parody

description: Dissonance that isn't resolved into full harmony
name: Partial Dopamine

description: Dissonance that isn't resolved into full harmony narrated by a child
name: Partial Dopamine + Perspective of a Child

description: Any plot decision designed to generate positive emotions in viewers.
name: Pivot into Positive Emotion

description: "The plot twist isn't a twist. It's the final link in a chain of untwisted events, where each link connects smoothly with the one before, carrying the story forward without bends or breaks. Yet even though the chain of the story is arrow straight, its final link is so stunning that it feels like a swerve. It overthrows all precedent, delivering us to a destination unexpected" (Fletcher 16).
name: Plot Twist

description: Rearranging our collective memory to help us relearn where we came from
name: Poetic History

description: A plot technology of having good things happen to "good" people and bad things happen to "bad" people
name: Poetic Justice

description:
Rearranges usual speech so that we slow down and notice things we wouldn't notice otherwise

Also called: Poetic Diction
name: Poetic Language

description: Rearranging a single element of a familiar story to help us see it afresh
name: Poetic Narrative

description: Presenting an alternate reality in the form of an absurd or unrealistic plot, character, or storyworld.
name: Reality Shifter

description: a narration technology that guides the reader to make an errant hypothesis that is then debunked
name: Red Herring

description: A plot technology that shows a character developing an elaborate punishment for a character who harmed a loved one.
name: Revenge Plot

description: A plot technology that shows a character developing an elaborate punishment for a character who harmed a loved one combined with a narration technology that allows readers or spectators to hear or read the inner conflict of the avenger.
name: Revenge Plot + Soliloquy

description: A narration technology that revisits something previously narrated to challenge its truth value
name: Second Look

description:
Dissonance before resolution

As theorized by Monteverdi, seconda practica
name: Second Method

description: A technology in which a narrator shares an intimate secret about a character. Sometimes the narrator is revealing their own secret and sometime another character's secret.
name: Secret Discloser

description: Any statement that supports our self, including a statement made by another person.
name: Self-Affirmation

description: A narration technology that prompts the reader to speak self-affirmations to themselves
name: Self-Self-Affirmation

description: A narration technology that presents a variety of cultural norms in a non-judgmental way, encouraging us to love and feel empathy for these characters
name: Shame Reducer

description: A narration technology that allows spectators or readers to hear or read the inner conflict of an individual character.
name: Soliloquy

description: A narration technology that allows readers to experience the inner conflict of (and therefore identify with) an individual character and then experience another character's conflict through that perspective.
name: Soliloquy in a Soliloquy

description: Grief Releaser (stalled plot) + Guilt Lifter (uniquely grieving character)
name: Sorrow Resolver

description:
A narration technology in which the character of one story becomes the narrator of another story

Also called: embedded narrative, story within a story, frame story, meta-story, mise en abyme
name: Story in the Story

description: A narration technology that allows the reader to witness the free flow of characters' inner thoughts
name: Stream of Consciousness

description:
"The taking of a regular pattern of plot or character or storyworld or narrative style or any other core component of story--any extending the pattern further. The stretch is the invention at the root of all literary wonder: the marvel that comes from stretching regular objects into metaphors, the dazzle that comes from stretching regular rhythms of speech into poetic meters, and the awe that comes from stretching regular humans into heroes" (Fletcher 17).

Also called: metaphor, poetic meter, repetition
name: Stretch

description: Revealing some part of the story, but not all of the pieces
name: Suspense

description: A narration technology that encourages you to a trust a narrator who is later revealed to be untrustworthy
name: Untrustworthy Narrator

description: Perhaps an anthology or database of reading experiences, like WonderCat :)
name: Varied Catalogue of Rhetorical Models

description: Adding an element to the story that does not fit without explanation
name: Vigilance Trigger

description: A narration technology that positions the all-knowing narrator as one of us.
name: Voice of "You and Me"

description: A plot technology that shows a character getting everything they want
name: Wish Fulfillment
xxx-I need to enter something new
